author: Danny_B08
title: Lego 76060 Doctor Strange's Sanctum Sanctorum
review:
One of the first things that caught my eye was the sticker sheet. I was slightly disappointed that on the box the window of the Sanctum Sanctorum has a backdrop however that is simply box art. Needless to say that is my only disappointment with this set! 

More noticeably on the sticker sheet was the letter from 'Stark Industries' which could be a spoiler for the film! Assuming it hints to an end credit scene of some sort?

As for the build, well its fantastic! The attention to detail is sublime and the functions included are pretty neat too! Although there are only 3 main functions I absolutely LOVE the spinning tentacles on the monster, which is controlled by a crank with gears on the back of the set. Another main function are the 2 clear poles in which you can sit (or stand) figures on and move and twist the pole from behind the set to give the illusion of he figures flying/floating. 
The last function is a tad confusing seeing as the film hasn't been released yet and that is the cloak holder to the left hand side of the set, the instructions tell you to place Strange's cloak on the joint and you can move it around (from behind the set again) as if it is moving on its own.

The build has more of a diorama feel to it rather than a generic lego set and to me it works very well! The bookshelves are brilliant and a stand out build in the set too, not to mention the build for the window!

Another little spoiler perhaps might be the red little gem they include in the set which is kept in the chest towards the left of the building, which might be an infinity gem of some kind, but that is just my pure speculation.

Lastly the figures. These are 3 fantastic figures! All three have double sided torso and head printings and all have leg printing too! 
The Ancient One's torso is gold and her new fan pieces are transparent with gold printing on them and look incredible!
Doctor Strange comes with two of the new grips for 2016 and these two awesome looking radar dish pieces in transparent and printed with gold lettering to give off the illusion he is casting a spell! Also noticeable for Steven Strange is the printed hair piece! Which looks brilliant with the white strands printed onto the black mould!
Lastly Karl Mordo is the 'generic' mini figure of the set but that means nothing as he still looks fantastic and comes with the newer afro hair piece for this year.

Overall the set is fantastic! For £29.99 I really can't complain, the 3 figures are brilliant, the functions are great fun and the set just looks amazing! 

 

Minifigures:

www.flickr.com/photos/66746510@N03/27894388934/in/dateposted-public/

Set:

www.flickr.com/photos/66746510@N03/28510720175/in/dateposted-public/

author: TK_1308
title: "What if I told you the reality you know is one of many."
review:
Lego releases it's first set from the upcoming Marvel film Doctor Strange, with Doctor Strange's Sanctum Sanctorum.

Box/Instructions

Mid range size rectangular box for a kit in this price range. The price per piece ratio is very good and more generous than other kits in this class.
Doctor Strange is the figure of choice on the top with a battle scene of all 3 figures next to him. The front and back show the playset with the figures battling the monster in the portal and the back has 4 other panels showing the play features.
Oddly enough, this small kit has 2 large rectangular instruction manuals where 1 would've been quite sufficient. Unlike other MCU sets, this one does not contain a comic.

Parts

A good number of parts in the kit, slightly more than usual for this price point. A nice mix of colours and small components for all the detailing and some great new pieces in the form of mystic spell generated effects.
There are 3 bags in the box. 
Bag 1 contains Doctor Strange, the base and lower walls of the sanctum letters, spell books and the two figure 'levitation stands'.
Bag 2 contains The Ancient One, the main walls of the sanctum and the portal monster.
Bag 3 contains Karl Mordo, the finishing touches to the walls, the trunk, bookcases, cloak stand, table and all the decorative touches to the set.

Minifigures

The set comes with 3 minifigures. These are all new releases for the MCU and the level of detailing and colour on all the minifigures is excellent.
Firstly we have Doctor Strange. This is a brilliant figure and a good likeness of the character. The detailing on the hair is a nice touch and the cloak with it's extended collar is brilliant. He has a two sided head with calm and fighting faces. He comes with two spell cast shields for his hands which are also wonderfully detailed with gold script.
Next up is Karl Mordo, long before he becomes Baron Mordo, one of Strange's enemies in the comics. A good attempt at capturing the likeness of his on-screen counterpart and he comes armed with a simple black staff weapon. He has a double sided head with calm and fighting faces.
Finally, we have The Ancient One. How close this is to the film version we can't say. In all the footage she seems to be wearing robes but this figure depicts her wearing what look like purple trousers and strapping over the robe top. It's still a great figure with a strangely enigmatic face which fits the character so well. She comes armed with 2 clear fans, sporting the same intricate gold text and Strange's spell cast shields.

The build

Total building time, 25 minutes.
It's a very straightforward build with nothing very complicated in the construction.
The designers have taken care to embrace the key things of the Sanctum Sanctorum in the design with the iconic round window, the bookcases of spell books and ancient maps, levers for the figures to sit on to make them appear to be levitating. 
The best part of the build is definitely the portal monster. Again, this has not featured in any trailer so it's either a surprise of the designer referenced the 90's Spider-Man animated series for ideas. Using technic gears and a simple rotary mechanism, it brings the playset to life with some great features. The maw and design is somewhat reminiscent of the Octopus from Aqua Raiders set 7775.
There are stickers, 8 in total, which are primarily decoration. The largest is the seal on the portal threshold, there are two large book covers and 5 letters. There are some nice references on these for fans.

The completed model

This kit is a very well put together playset and a nice display piece in itself. For a small set, it certainly has a lot of detailing and features to add to the look and feel of Strange's Sanctum. Skulls, chests, bottles, chains, letters, maps, spell books - the set is littered with nice little touches like this.
The levitation levers can be controlled from the back and figures can sit floating in the air or they can fly if desired. They can move in and out of the set as well as arcing about 60 degrees vertically
There is one on the left for Strange to hang his mystic cape on as well.
The best feature in the whole set is definitely the portal creature. The bright red tentacles are very poseable with joints mid point on the four larger ones. Using the rotary mechanism on the back, the maw rotates with the 4 large teeth and the tentacles swirl and thrash. If positioned correctly, turning the mechanism allows the tentacles to close and ensnare a minifigure. It has 4 eyes on a disc but these do not rotate with the rest.
The Sanctum measures 29 cm across, 13 cm deep (at the portal end) and 10 cm high.

Overall opinion

Like Ant-Man, I suspect that this may be the only release connected with this film. As such, Marvel fans will want to get this set for the characters to round out the growing MCU series of minifigures. This is a great little playset, full of detail, some fun play features and has 3 exclusive (so far) figures so what other reason do you need to buy this great kit.

author: Khscarymovie
title: One Of The Best Lego Marvel Sets Ever.
review:
76060 Doctor Strange's Sanctum Sanctorum is a Lego Marvel set based off the 2016 MCU film Doctor Strange. It offers an incredible build and amazing minifigure's. 

Minifigure's 

The minifigure's in this set are Doctor Strange, Karl Mordo, and The Ancient One. Doctor Strange is a fantastic minifigure, very detailed. The only complaint I have about this minifigure is the hair is nor accurate to the movie version of Doctor Strange. Karl Mordo is a perfect minifigure and I can't think of anything wrong with him. The Ancient One is another great minifigure but is not very accurate to the movie version. 

Build

The build of the set is based off Doctor Strange's Sanctum Sanctorum, which is basically Doctor Strange's house. Instead of having a location build that consist of walls blowing up and prisoners being freed, this build is more like the one in the Big Bang Theory set, and I love it for that. The build is very detailed and litters with easter eggs. The monster coming through the portal is a very neat build, and I expect we might get something like this in a future Star Wars set with a rathtar. I think the window is also very nicely done. I love all the treasures and books in the bookcases, I feel kids could create interesting story's about how Doctor Strange got these items. 

Parts

I think the price is incredible for how Many parts you get. I think there are some very interesting parts here, my favorite are probably Doctor Strange's little dishes that he fight with. 

Overall

Overall I think this is one of the best Lego Marvel sets ever. It has an amazing build and fantastic minifigure's, and it's for a very cheap price. I would definitely recommend it.

author: andyh1984
title: looks better than it plays, but looks great.
review:
A great looking set but lacking playability.

Box/Instructions

A rectangular box showing the set on the front and the set and features on the back.

For some reason there are 2 instruction booklets where everything would fit into one easily. No mini-comic

Parts

A great use of some standard parts and more unusual parts both in imaginative ways.

Minifigures

All three Minifigures are superbly detailed, I don't know my Doctor Strange characters very well so I don't know the significance of Karl Mordo or the Ancient One or the accuracy of their costume but Doctor Strange's costume looks very authentic to movie images I've seen.

The build

Not as long as I had hoped but an involved and interesting build nonetheless, the bookcases, window and portal monster stand out.

The completed model

This set looks great with lots of detail some of which is stickers.

Overall opinion

I like this set but it is not without some niggles. 

The "floating cloak" hanger looks out of place when not being used and I suspect that will be most of the time for both adults and children, maybe trans-clear pieces would have been better but some pieces aren't available in that colour (it is removable if you don't like it).

It is difficult if not impossible to get the tentacles to "grab" a minifigure to pull towards the portal especially as the area in front of the portal is sloped.

That said this is a good looking model but one which is light on playability for children, maybe because we don't know what action takes place in this room.

author: legopeople101
title: Sanctum Sanctorum review 2016
review:
This set has very fun play features which kids will really enjoy if they have this set.

The price for the set is fair.

The design of the set and the minifigures are very accurate to the film.

I think the set needs to be slightly larger and maybe add 1 or 2 more minifigs e.g Kaecilius.

Otherwise this is a great lego set and i highly recommend it. This set is perfect to add to you Marvel cinematic universe collection. :)

author: Duck_Entity_420
title: Doctor Strange review
review: The set is amazing.  Love the play feature with the portal beast.  I think however that this set is more of a display piece then a play set which I don't have a problem with.  My only complaint with this set is that when I look at the price I expect 4 minifigures (Kaecilius PLZ).  But either than that its a gr8 marvel set!

author: Odeinoichus
title: Shuma Gorath, I Have NOT Come to Bargain.
review:
Set #76060 Doctor Strange’s Sanctum Sanctorum: The Marvel Cinematic Universe has been represented since 2012 with many different LEGO Marvel sets. To represent the Doctor Strange film LEGO gave us this set, which features an interesting looking structure and three Minifigures to join the likes of Captain America and Iron Man. This set has been retiring soon, perhaps by the point of this review it’s finally off LEGO’s site for purchasing, and if you want every MCU set you’re going to want to get this set.

However there’s still much to discuss before we get to that point of the review, so let’s start with the usual features of a LEGO Marvel set.

Box/Instructions

Box: Benedict Cumberbatch as Doctor Strange invites you to pick up his LEGO set in the upper corner of the box and the MCU logo for the movie is found in the lower corner making no doubt what this set represents. The box itself is the same basic design we’ve seen before from the Theme, nothing to note that hasn’t been discussed ad-nausea in all of my past reviews.

Instructions: The build is broken up through numbered bags as usual, and split between two numbered manuals. Both manuals are definitely easy to follow along with, there are some stickers for detailing which require precise placement, however the rest of the build is fairly easy to follow along with in both manuals. The only cross-promotional images in the back are for the Spider-Man sets of 2016 and the LEGO Marvel Avengers video game, there was no comic book included in this set.

Parts

There’s a large number of common parts in this set, with a few rare elements such as the reverse curved slopes used for the windows. You’ll also find a few wall parts and some large blade pieces first introduced in LEGO Ninjago, not much else to say here, it’s a pretty good parts pack honestly.

Minifigures

Doctor Strange: This is the second time Benedict Cumberbatch has appeared in LEGO form, his first ever character was Smaug from The Hobbit range. This Minifigure is his first Minifigure appearance though and it captures his look quite nicely.

He has an impressive level of detail with his double-sided torso featuring the Eye of Agamotto and his leg printing with some sashes. His hair piece has been used many times before, but this one features side-printing to show the whiteness of his iconic hair style. He has two facial expressions, a stern looking facial expression and an angry teeth gritting expression. For accessories he gets two printed dishes to represent astral based energy blasts, which are attached to the newer clip based accessory with a single stud on it introduced with the Spider-Man sets. He’s a great looking figure.

Karl Mordo: Also decked out in a considerable amount of detailing, Mordo shows off even more sashes and tunics on his torso and leg prints. He also uses Fin’s hair piece, his face is also double-sided with two different stern or angry expressions… Man these mystics never seem to want to smile. He has a long black staff piece for his accessory and that’s pretty much it.

The Ancient One: I have no idea what this outfit is that she’s wearing, considering she never wore anything like this in the movie, however her torso and leg printing is equally as detailed as her students. With a nice pearl gold torso she’s sporting either a pair of odd purple suspenders or some sort of mystic sash thing draping down over her shoulders. Two fan accessories in clear ABS plastic with some writing printing on it for film accuracy represent her arsenal against the dreaded Shuma-Gorath. She features back printing on her head for mystic markings, but no dual-sided facial expressions because… well she has nothing to cover up with. As bald as Lex Luthor this one.

The build

Bag 1: You first begin the build with Doctor Strange and the floor of the façade that represents a part of the Sanctum Sanctorum. This build is pretty simple and straight forward, the only difficult bit would perhaps be the placement of the clear Minifigure control rods, or you know, whatever the official name is for those parts first introduced in LEGO Studios for brick-films. Getting them to fit just right can be a bit frustrating because they aren’t meant to connect to anything as they are part of a gimmick.

Bag 2: The Ancient One joins Doctor Strange and continues the build of the Façade with further construction of the wall and the open portal where the dangerous looking tentacle beast from the Fifth Dimension, or wherever Shuma Gorath comes from, is completed. This portion of the build is also fairly simple, however the geared gimmick for the monster can be a bit tricky to get placed just right. The gears really love to move when you’re trying to build up that area of the model.

Nothing else about this build stood out to me, aside from the window construction, the techniques and parts used here are very ingenious and I really enjoy the look they achieve.

Bag 3: Karl Mordo joins the Minifigures here and the rest of the detail work is built up, book cases and display cases and the last portion of the wall. This build is much quicker and very easy to finish off, the bookcases are really fun and similar to other sets who have built such cases. Such as Big Bang Theory or Vampyre Castle. Ultimately I enjoyed the build, it wasn’t another silly Marvel vehicle, but an actual playset and as we’re about to discuss it looks very fun and involves some clever details and enjoyable play features.

The completed model

Sanctum Sanctorum: This is another one of those models where the devil is in the details. Everything about it is full of great detailing, with limited and rather unobtrusive play features.

The biggest draw of your eye is the dark Shuma-Gorath entity exploding out of some mystical portal in the wall. Perhaps a summoning gone bad. Behind the wall is a bunch of gear pieces used in tandem to flail the tentacles about and attempt to capture a Minifigure. (When placed just right the four tentacles actually can grab and hold a Minifigure.)

The central section has a large open window with a very clever build design and a table. There are two large book cases on either side of this section and two small stands that can bob up and down so you can simulate the mystical ability of the characters to fly or leap up and hover in the air. More great fun.

The end just features a treasure chest and a small area to place the Cloak of Levitation which floats up and down on another clever little gimmick. I’m not a fan of having to take the cloak off Doctor Strange though, it’s rather frustrating to get on him in the first place until you know how to fold it just right to line up the holes all properly, so having to take it on and off just to make it hover in the corner is a bit annoying. It would have been nicer to get two capes to use, even if it meant that Strange would still be wearing his cloak while one was hovering in the corner of his Sanctum.

Overall opinion

If you want a Doctor Strange Minifigure for your MCU Minifigure collection, this is the only set to feature him so far, even if he appears in Thor Ragnarok he has not appeared in either set. So I’d definitely recommend picking this one up. The façade that is the Sanctum Sanctorum is even more impressive, and certainly should not be missed. It’s loaded with great details, awesome play features, and brilliant Minifigures. So strongly recommended.

author: Faefrost
title: A delightful little set
review:
Welcome to the top floor of 177A Bleeker St, Greenwich Village, NY. The abode of the Sorcerer Supreme (spoiler for the next movie as he hasn't taken the title yet) Dr. Stephen Strange. For fans of the comics and the movie, this set represents the "Summoning Chamber" on the uppermost floor. That sits right behind the buildings Mystical Seal, the Window. 

The Lego set while being based on the recent movie, does pull a lot from the comics. The color tones, decor and layout more cosely match how it is depicted most often in the comics. The minifigs are pure movie. It's an interesting set in that it feels like it is targeted to an older age range than most of the other Lego Super Hero sets. It is a nice highly detailed room interior with lots of little things like appointed book shelves and tables. What stickers there are are mainly for mail and papers that add detail. It reminds me a lot of some of the Hobbit or Lord of the Ring sets. Particularly Unexpected Gathering and Mines of Moria. It has quite a few action or play features. But they both feel subtle or subdued, and more than a bit out of place. Please don't be scared off by what I am saying, this really is a superb set. One of the best Marvel sets of the year. Certainly one of the more distinct ones. 

Box/Instructions - The Box art is great. The box art is a full frame zoom in so the viewer feels like he is sitting in front of the room that is the build. Framed very much like a TV sitcom. All the action and feelings of movement are staged within the set itself. It is a quite striking effect. There are some faint neutral borders around the edges and a fake NYC scape painting behind the Seal Window. The box shows the three characters Strange, (Baron) Mordo and The Ancient One fighting the tentacled beast from the dark dimension that is coming through the summoning portal. The Back of the box shows a more close up look at the various bits and how each play feature works. Instructions are 2 thick stapled booklets. Curled and stuffed in the box like greasy buritos in a Taco Bag. 

Minifigs - The set comes with three Minifigs, which is one of the few complaints I have with it. It gives us;

Dr. Strange -  with his Cloak of Levitation. Strange is a gorgeous figure who looks exactly as you knew he should. Dark blue with front and back printing and leg printing. His hair piece is the slightly peaked one commonly used for Vampires and J Jonah Jameson, in Black, but with white striping painted on at the temples. It looks good. His torso includes printing of the Eye of Agamoto on a chain around his neck. he also includes two new 3mm grip peg studs and 2 2x2 trans clear dishes printed with golden spells on them. They nicely capture the effect of him casting spells. They do suffer a little as the gold printing on them is a bit fine and doesn't catch the light as well as you might wish for. You have to look closely to see how really beautiful these things are. The cloak of Levitation is a single piece of fabric, cut so that you fold it four times to get the desired pointed collar and cloak effect. It looks and works as expected. The most interesting element to it is it has its own play feature. Take in off Dr Starange and attach it to the Cloak Hook on the left side of the room. And you can have it float around and help as a disembodied cloak. It's an awkward but cute play feature. Although It might be worth Bricklinking an extra cloak to leave permanently attached there. The folding at the neck is complex and the neck peg goes through four layers of cloth. Taking it on and off both the figure and the stand repeatedly will cause it to fray.

The Ancient One - She is a gorgeous figure, I'm just not quite sure how well they captures the movie Ancient One. Her torso is dual sided gold printing over a pearl gold base. her legs are purple with gold printing. Her head is... odd. In the movie she is completely bald. Her figures head has her neutral slightly smiling face, but the back of her head has this strange pink cross hatching. Wrinkles? Razor Marks? Some design element from concept art that didn't make it into the movie? Who knows. The best thing about her figure is her two gorgeous fans. Like Strange's spells these are trans clear with a ton of fine gold printing. It really gives them a glowing golden ethereal feel. Perfect for the character. 

Mordo - The final figure is (Baron) Karl Mordo. Strange's fellow student of the Ancient One. He is the most basic of the three. His main color scheme is dark green with front and back printed robes on his torso and legs. His weapon is a stick. Just a normal Lego 3mm shaft to represent the 'Staff of the Living Tribunal". Rather boring. He has a dual sided face. Each nicely captures his slightly stubly beard and his expressions. He uses the same short curly slightly Afro'd hair piece that we first saw with the Falcon. he looks good. If you want to jazz him up to look more like his fellows, Get a section of Lego Chain in a trans color. Trans Neon Green or Trans Orange, to show his staff in its Whip mode.

Perhaps the biggest negative of the set is it only has three figs. Since we only got the one Dr. Strange set it really cries out for one or two more figs. We need Wong and maybe a Cultist.

Parts -  The parts selection is excellent. The delicate printing on Stranges Spells and the Ancient Ones fans are unique to the set and are outstanding. Lots of uses for each. The remainder of the set offers a nice assortment of parts useful for building rooms and interiors. You could nicely decorate a Modular Building's rooms with what comes in this set. 

Build and Model - The build is quite straightforward. You work your way through the baseplate and bottom of the back wall. Add the action features and finish the Mystic Seal and Tentacled Horror, Then fill in the walls. The third bag adds the furnishings. Each bookshelf and table is a nice micro build. 

The finished model looks great. A nice little backdrop that you can display your figures in front of. Its (limited) play features are the knob that spins the tentacles making them wave and swirl and grab minifigs in a surge of Lovecraftian Horror. There are two character levetation arms, one on either side of the Mystic Seal. They are... well lets be honest they are as useless as they are in every other set that Lego has tried them in, going back to the horrid Star Wars Dual of the Fates set. But at least here they are small, unobtrusive and they can tuck away. The final action feature is the slightly different lift arm for the Cloak of Levitation. As I said above it's cute. But it looks odd without the cloak on it. If you will be displaying this set, I suggest Bricklinking a second cloak, just to leave one permanently on the play arm. There are lots of maps, pictures and printed and stickered documents reflecting Strange's research. 

Overall - This is a stunning small set. It is a room portion done right. Rather like the Big Bang Theory set or the Hobbit or LotR sets named above. It sets the scene perfectly and lets you play out something, if not quite from the movie (The tentacle beast from hell is actually in Guardians of the Galaxy 2, Not Dr. Strange) it certainly has the sort of look and feel to perfectly match a classic scene as drawn by Steve Ditko. So the set manages to bridge the best of both worlds. I would categorize this one as a must have for Marvel Collectors. While we may see another Dr. Strange fig in Thor or Avengers sets (He's confirmed for Thor Ragnarok and Avengers Infinity War) We will not soon get another Ancient One or Baron Mordo figure. This is a set you as an AFOL can leave out on your bookshelf and friends wont question why you have toys on the shelf at your age.

One word of caution. The set does seem to be targeted a little older. I know the box says 7-14, and the build isn't that complex. But the actual set may not be as engaging for the younger end of the age spectrum. The older 9-14 kids or beyond will love it. And it is pure crack fro AFOL's.
